By ‘best’ I guess you mean a company that offers the best platform for you to train and debut? I suggest you set your priority first. In my opinion, SM has the most complete training system and the mentors are top notch in this industry. You’d definitely learn a lot at SM. But they tend to have too many trainees that only few of them get to debut. JYP and YG have very specific preferences for selecting trainees. Go watch their artists performing and you’d understand what I mean. I don’t know if you fit into their ‘concept’. If you don’t, you won’t get to debut no matter how good you are. However, both companies are good at making their artists popular. I’m Starship biased but I don’t think it’s big enough to make all their artists successful. It takes tons of money to build a hype machine in Kpop after all. This goes the same with other smaller companies, where they offer bigger chance for you to debut though. If you’re interested in smaller companies, make sure you read past news reports about them to filter out problematic ones. Some mentioned Big Hit. I can’t say much about it since it only has Lee Hyun and BTS members in its talent pool. What works for BTS won’t necessarily happen to their future artists. Nethertheless, SM, JYP and YG have their ‘family’ stan, perhaps Big Hit’s new artists can also benefit from this family love. The only thing I’m sure about Big Hit is they’ve got sufficient money made by BTS to offer better stuff for their trainees. If you want to produce your own art, you’d be welcome in any company. It’s an urban legend that certain companies encourage creative activities while others don’t. NO. All Kpop companies love talents. AND it’s been a trend that the companies recruit more members who can do their own music and choreography.
